node.title: How to find the areal mean of a 3D variable
node.bodyText:
Hi, everyone.
I have a 3D square flow channel, and I want to calculate the convective heat transfer coefficient of its walls, which requires me to get the Reynolds number. In a 3D model, the velocity is a function of (x, y, z) and I want to know the average velocity at z. This requires an area integral of velocity(x,y,z) on the xy plane, and then dividing by the channel area on the xy plane. Similarly, material properties rho, mu, k, cp are also functions of (x, y, z), and I want to get their average value at coordinate z. What object should be used in MOOSE to accomplish this?

Hello
There is an AreaPostprocessor, you ll just need to add a sideset on what you want to measure
Guillaume

I take a look at AreaPostprocessor , but I don't think it might solve my problem. I think my description might not be very clear. Imagine that, you have a square pipe with fluid flowing through it. And you want to get the Reynolds number of the fluid along the pipe and use it as a Material or Postprocessor for subsequent coupling calculations. So how to get the average velocity of water in each radial section in the pipe?

You can take an take an average using the ratio of a volumetric flow rate postprocessor and the area postprocessor
There is also a volumetric Reynolds postprocessor you can use
This is a very enlightening approach. It helped me a lot.

You can use the SideAverageValue postprocessor to find the value of a variable over a sideset.  You can also inherit from it and override computeQpIntegral() to find the average of anything you can compute.
Here is the doco for that: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/SideAverageValue.html
For flow sims, the VolumetricFlowRate is better. Works across discretizations and lets you consider whichever quantities you could really want (average velocity is rarely the one)

Hi, experts. I have tried some methods these days, but still can't get the effect I want. I will rephrase my problem again, and for the convenience of testing and understanding, I will introduce it with a two-dimensional model. And generalization from 2D to 3D is easy.
I have a model of fluid-solid conjugate heat transfer. Obviously, the convective heat transfer coefficient at the fluid-solid interface should be a function of flow conditions (eg velocity):

I want to get htc using Peclet number, and I created a Peclet number in Materials block:
  [./Pe_fluid]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = Pe
    function = 'speed * ${L} / (k / (rho * cp))'
    material_property_names = 'k rho cp'
    args = 'speed'
    block = fluid
  [../]

Now there is a Pe on each element in the fluid area. In other words, Pe is a function of x and y, that is, Pe=f(x,y). But htc is a function of y. So I want to get the mean of Pe at each y. For sidesets, I only have sidesets of boundaries. Is there any object in MOOSE that can achieve this?

you should have a look at the layered average objects, that does exactly that, in many variations
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobject/NearestPointLayeredAverage.html

Can this object be used in coupled computations? Obviously, htc affects velocity (or Pe), which in turn affects htc. If I get the average Pe by using this object, can objects in other blocks use the results?

This stores the result in an auxiliary variable.
That auxiliary variable may be coupled anywhere afterwards

I used LayeredAverage to get layer average value, so that I can avoid setting the Points in NearestPointLayeredAverage. The method I use is cumbersome and superfluous (in the opinion of someone who is proficient in MOOSE) and I encountered some problems when I use the htc.
If I want to know the layer average value of Pe or Nu, then I need to know the layer average values of rho, cp, k and speed. So I first use ADMaterialRealAux to take out the rho, cp, k of the fluid area in Materials, and store them in the AuxVariables rho_fluid, cp_fluid, k_fluid. Then I use SpatialUserObjectAux and LayeredAverage to get the layer average values of rho_fluid, cp_fluid, k_fluid and store them in new AuxVariables ave_rho_fluid, ave_cp_fluid, ave_k_fluid. Finally I use ADParsedMaterial block to define the Pe and Nu I want in Materials block, and use Nu and ave_k_fluid to get htc. The related syntax is here:
[AuxVariables]
  [./speed]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./ave_speed]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./rho_fluid]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./ave_rho_fluid]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./k_fluid]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./ave_k_fluid]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./cp_fluid]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./ave_cp_fluid]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  
  [./Pe]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./Nu]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./heat_tran_coeff]
    family = MONOMIAL
	order = CONSTANT
	block = 'fluid'
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./speed_auxk]
    type = VectorVariableMagnitudeAux
	variable = speed
	vector_variable = velocity
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_speed_auxk]
    type = SpatialUserObjectAux
	variable = ave_speed
	user_object = ave_speed_uo
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./rho_fluid_auxk]
    type = ADMaterialRealAux
	property = 'rho'
	variable = rho_fluid
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_rho_fluid_auxk]
    type = SpatialUserObjectAux
	variable = ave_rho_fluid
	user_object = ave_rho_fluid_uo
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./k_fluid_auxk]
    type = ADMaterialRealAux
	property = 'k'
	variable = k_fluid
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_k_fluid_auxk]
    type = SpatialUserObjectAux
	variable = ave_k_fluid
	user_object = ave_k_fluid_uo
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./cp_fluid_auxk]
    type = ADMaterialRealAux
	property = 'cp'
	variable = cp_fluid
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_cp_fluid_auxk]
    type = SpatialUserObjectAux
	variable = ave_cp_fluid
	user_object = ave_cp_fluid_uo
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./Pe_auxk]
    type = ADMaterialRealAux
	property = 'Pelect_Number'
	variable = Pe
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./Nu_auxk]
    type = ADMaterialRealAux
	property = 'Nusselt_Number'
	variable = Nu
	block = fluid
  [../]
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./ave_speed_uo]
    type = LayeredAverage
	direction = y
	num_layers = 11
	variable = speed
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_rho_fluid_uo]
    type = LayeredAverage
	direction = y
	num_layers = 11
	variable = rho_fluid
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_k_fluid_uo]
    type = LayeredAverage
	direction = y
	num_layers = 11
	variable = k_fluid
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./ave_cp_fluid_uo]
    type = LayeredAverage
	direction = y
	num_layers = 11
	variable = cp_fluid
	block = fluid
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./rho_fluid_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = rho
    function = '(11096 - 1.3236 * Tf) * 1e-6'
    args = 'Tf'
    block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./cp_fluid_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = cp
    function = '159 - 2.72e-2 * Tf + 7.12e-6 * pow(Tf,2)'
    args = 'Tf'
    block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./k_fluid_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = k
    function = '(3.61 + 1.517e-2 * Tf - 1.741e-6 * pow(Tf,2)) * 1e-2'
    args = 'Tf'
    block = 'fluid'
  [../]
  [./mu_fluid_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = mu
    function = '4.94e-6 * exp(754.1/Tf)'
    args = 'Tf'
    block = 'fluid'
  [../]

  [./Pelect_Number_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
	f_name = Pelect_Number
	function = 'ave_speed * ${L} / (ave_k_fluid / (ave_rho_fluid * ave_cp_fluid))'
	args = 'ave_speed ave_k_fluid ave_rho_fluid ave_cp_fluid'
	block = fluid
  [../]
  [./Nusselt_Number_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
	f_name = Nusselt_Number
	function = '5.75 + 0.022 * pow(Pelect_Number, 0.8)'
	material_property_names = 'Pelect_Number'
	block = fluid
  [../]
  
  [./htc_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
	f_name = htc
	function = '(Nusselt_Number * ave_k_fluid) / ${L}'
	material_property_names = 'Nusselt_Number'
	args = 'ave_k_fluid'
	#function = '${heat_transfer_coefficient}'
	block = fluid
  [../]
[]

But when I run the input file, it can't converge:
Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1

Performing automatic scaling calculation

Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0

Aborting as solve did not converge

..............................................................................................................................................................

Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

To test if the previous AuxVaiables would get the results I want, I set htc to a constant and run the input file.
 
The above figures show that Nu and Pe are calculated successfully, but why does it not converge when I use Nu to calculate htc and use the htc? Here are input files and mesh files.
2d.zip

What were you using previously for Nu and Pe? constants?
Can you try isolating it to either Nu or Pe?
I didn't set Nu and Pe before and set htc equal to a constant. But such simulations are very imprecise. So I want to use Nu to calculate htc.
can you set them to constants and see what convergence is like? One at a time

node.title: How to get the normal vector to a sideset( nodeset)?
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team,
I am using the "CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier" to simulate the boundary movement between two blocks. The velocity of the moving boundary (let's say V) is controlled by a coupled variable c (in my example: mass concentration). However, the direction of the movement should be perpendicular to the boundary. Therefore, the boundary-moving function should look something like this:
X=X0+V(c)* t * [nx, ny, nz],
where [nx, ny, nz] is the normal vector to the boundary at point (x,y,z) and time t.
Is there a userobject or auxiliary variable in Moose that I can use to find the normal vector? If not, what is your advice?
Best regards,
Kavan

hello
You can get the sides from the _current_elem (a class attribute to this user object), with a loop on the sides using this routine to retrieve them.
https://libmesh.github.io/doxygen/classlibMesh_1_1Elem.html#a9c669d37f9a794d933bae07babc2eb60
then from these you can get the normal (with a cross product for example), once you've checked that the side is part of the boundary you care about with something like this for example:
https://libmesh.github.io/doxygen/classlibMesh_1_1BoundaryInfo.html#a99bb67d6ae6c470d2cbfdb232dae609e
(this one in particular uses the element and the side index, not the side element)

Guillaume

node.title: Looooong time for Setting Up
node.bodyText:
I am running a fairly vanilla job using the Ferret app. No problems with reasonably large meshes (some 500k nodes). But when I try something more like a production-level mesh with 24M nodes and 18M tets, I run into problems. If I try to run --mesh-only to split the mesh, the execution chews on "Setting Up" for a long long time (timed out after 24 hrs on 96 MPI tasks). Same hppens if I run with --check-input. This is not a memory problem and I believe it is not specific to the app but rather something goofy in my framework build (all tests run fine, and I have no issues with small or medium sized problems). How can I figure out what gets the system hung up on "Setting Up"? It seems to me a mesh with some 24M nodes should not be a big deal if I have enough MPI tasks and memory to go around.
Thanks!

Are you getting any "live prints" coming out (something like "Reading Mesh ......")  You may want to try bumping up the output level of the PerfGraph to get more information printing out:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/outputs/PerfGraphOutput.html

There's also a script to help you find the culprit: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py
IIRC this script assumes pbs, but it shouldn't be too hard to adapt it for slurm.
Can you please paste your mesh block here as well please?

Thanks, guys. I will try these things tomorrow, and also paste in the mesh
block.

Martini-time now.

Cheers,
Olle

I did a more careful check using htop of what is going on. I ran this on my
linux workstation that has 96 GB of RAM. That should by all accounts work
for a 4 GB meshfile if I use distributed mesh on 24 MPI processes using
--distributed-mesh, and also another run with
 --mesh-only --split-mesh 24
 in the command line. Monitoring the memory usage I noted that the MPI root
task was using up to about 10 GB while the other 23 tasks were using some
insignificant amount  of memory. But suddenly *all* tasks start to up their
memory usage (2 GB, 3GB, up towards 4 GB) and that causes the job to crash
because it runs out of memory.

This suggests that there is something wrong (my install?) with how
distributing the mesh is being handled - it appears that in spite of the
--split-mesh, all tasks are using up memory corresponding to the size of
the mesh file.

Any ideas???

Typically this does not happen. We sometimes serialize the mesh on rank 0, never serialize it on all ranks starting from a distributed one

node.title: Wanna learn to use ADKernelSUPG for application development
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone!
I am using MOOSE to build an application to simulate the transient single-phase flow using three basic equations and several state equations, and now it comes to the final part.
In the transient simulation, the oscillation happens near the boundary, leading to not converging at certain time step. So I am trying to use some stablization methods like SUPG used in the NS module.
Then I look into the NS kernels, finding that there is a basic kernel called ADKernelSUPG which is the base class of many ns kernels, so I am trying to make use of the Kernel to compute the stablization terms.
However, I cannot find tutorial on how to use this kernel for development on the offical website. Could you help me with learning to use ADKernelSUPG and Kernels like that? Like examples or docs and things like that.
Thank you so much!

Hello
I'm afraid the actual development of the NS module, especially the INSAD implementation, is not documented beyond the doxygen
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classADKernelSUPGTempl.html
and the modules FE description
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/navier_stokes/cgfe.html
@lindsayad do you know of any more SUPG documentation out there?
Before you attempt to use SUPG, have you made sure your implementation is correct? By doing verification & validation on simple cases? see this post #22344 for details on verification
Guillaume

The only class in MOOSE that inherits directly from ADKernelSUPG (the scalar field form) is INSADEnergySUPG. I think that doc page, although short, is helpful. Essentially you need to do 3 things:

provide a material property describing tau
provide a vector variable velocity
implement precomputeQpStrongResidual. You could do this on a strong term basis, e.g. if you have three terms in your PDE, create three kernels that inherit from ADKernelSUPG. Or you could do something like what is done in INSADEnergySUPG where only one kernel is used to gather the contributions from all terms in the PDE (those contributions are held in a material property _temperature_strong_residual)

Strong term/strong form just means your PDE before you convert it to the weak form for finite element discretization.

Thanks for your reply!
I will try on it  :)

node.title: Results changed by slightly adjust executioner block
node.bodyText:
Hi guys, so i'm running a simple porousflow simulation for mining application by increasing permeability at the middle part (cave) the model for each SS run consecutively ie frame1 > frame2 > frame3, now we only look at how the phreatic surface (pwp =0) move for each frame, it's supposed to be bigger as frame progress.
lets say here is frame1 this is the result and its [Executioner]
[Executioner]
type = Steady
solve_type = NEWTON
petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg '
nl_rel_tol = 1e-14
nl_abs_tol = 2e2
l_tol = 1e-06
l_max_its = 100
nl_max_its = 100
line_search = 'none' 
[]


The result is as expected
so the next frame (frame2_v1), I used the result of frame1 as the initial condition and ran with the same [Executioner]
this is what i got

it seems to be smaller, which is incorrect
then I changed the [Executioner] to
[Executioner]
type = Steady
solve_type = NEWTON
petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg '
nl_rel_tol = 1e-14
nl_abs_tol = 2e2
l_tol = 1e-06
l_max_its = 100
nl_max_its = 100
line_search = 'bt' 
[]

and I got the expected results (frame2_v2)

idk why this is the case, sometimes I increase nl_abs_tol = 2e2 to 3e2 re-run and it changes the way my simulation run > more non-linear steps etc, there is something that isn't so stable.
more findings when comparing the darcy_vel
frame1

frame2_v1 (obviously looks really bad)

frame2_v2 (back to normal)

so the [Executioner] is the only control factor of my results, note that, all cases are converged around the same residual
note: only
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg 

works with my workflow, the models are huge and complex, we have tried other solvers, but they wouldn't work.
Please let me know if you have any idea
Kind regards,
Traiwit

2e2 for the absolute residual seems huge, the relative tolerance is fine but probably doesnt matter with such a large residual criterion
Could you please turn on automatic_scaling = true
then try to make sure every variable is sufficiently converged.
There s show_var_residual_norms in the [Debug] block you may use for that

node.title: Sliding at GB
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
In their work on Salt Rocks' deformation mechanism, colleagues have observed sliding at GB before the
cracking starts. We are trying to model this feature under MOOSE. I have some development running (almost) fine with PF fracture coupled to  CP, but would like to know if there's a  way in moose to introduce this Sliding at GB without throwing all and restarting from scratch.
Thank you for any help
Saber

How do you model your GB? sharp or diffuse interface?
If it is sharp, I guess you can use cohesive zone method to model GB sliding.
I will be interested in both diffuse and sharp. At room temperature it is mainly sharp, but we expect different behaviour with increasing temperature.
Is there an already programmed meshModifier to split the mesh at the GB ? I am working with randomly generated grains.

Is there an already programmed meshModifier to split the mesh at the GB ? I am working with randomly generated grains.

Take a look at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/BreakMeshByBlockGenerator.html

Back to moose after one year of Abaqus to discover that I could not split my mesh at the GB.
The grain number and properties are made at the MAterial block, how to tell the mesh breaker to create interfaces at GB ?
I have something like:
[Mesh]
[./fmg]
type = FileMeshGenerator
file=eprouvette.msh
[]
[]
[UserObjects]
[./prop_read]
type = ElementPropertyReadFile
prop_file_name = 'input_euler.txt'
nprop = 4
read_type = grain
ngrain = 200
rand_seed =7777
[../]
[]

and at the material block:
[./elasticity_tensor]
type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
C_ijkl = '4.9592 2.670 2.670 4.9592 2.670 4.9592 3.111 3.111 3.111'
fill_method = symmetric9
read_prop_user_object = prop_read
[../]

Regards,
Saber

Are you trying to create a sideset at the grain boundaries?
You can use a SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator in [Mesh] for that
Or partition the computation?

I want to use CZM at GB. So i need to generate
these side sets.
Regards

Are the grains a separate subdomain? What do you see in the exodus output?
If so, then the mesh generator I pointed you to should work
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator.html

Lets take an example with 4 grains like in : ~/projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/elem_prop_read_user_object/prop_elem_read.i
is it possible in this case to introduce nodes to make interfaces for CZM to be considered at GB ?
regards,

What are the grains in the example? I m not sure.
This example has 4 elements and reads data per element.
Is there a variable defined on these grains? A material property?
How do you know what the grain boundaries are?
That is my question from the beginning, how to tell the mesh modifier about the grain boundaries.

czm_traction_separation_base.i
czm_patch_test_base.i
czm_multiple_dimension_base.i
czm_multiple_action_and_materials.i

node.title: *.inp Data Array
node.bodyText: I am reading Abacus inp mesh files generated by somebody else. The mesh files contain Data Arrays with different names, one of which ("Materials Id")  I want to use as tag for materials properties. If I were using Cubit I would assign block ids corresponding to the materials tag in the inp file. My question is: how to I assign materials properties in the moose input file that map onto the Materials Id in the inp file?

Hello
We have support for what we call extra element integer IDs that can be attached to elements.
However, the Abaqus input file reader does not currently read extra fields to fill those extra element integer IDs. So that ll incur some development.
Guillaume

Thanks, Guillaume. I can export the file to an exodus format where
material_id shows up as a Block Array. Can that be read from the exodus
file?
…
-Olle
On Wed, Jun 22, 2022 at 12:15 PM Guillaume Giudicelli < ***@***.***> wrote:
 Hello

 We have support for what we call extra element integer IDs that can be
 attached to elements.
 However, the Abaqus input file reader does not currently read extra fields
 to fill those extra element integer IDs. So that ll incur some development.

 Guillaume

 —
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#21381 (comment)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AEKZEFY7VZT7W76OADS7ZXLVQNC4FANCNFSM5ZQ5R64A>
 .
 You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>


-- 
Olle Heinonen
***@***.***
I m not familiar with that
@roystgnr

Maybe?  We have a method, libMesh::ExodusII_IO::set_extra_integer_vars(vector<string>), that tells a read() to look for elemental variables with the specified names and read them into our extra-id values.  And Moose has a parameter, exodus_extra_element_integers in FileMeshGenerator, to interface with that from a user input file.  But I haven't really touched that code myself (except to fix a nasty bug that cropped up in it), and it's a bit of a hack (it only works on values which can be represented as both our internal integer dof_id_type and the Exodus float type they're written to), and I'm not sure what it maps to under the hood in the Exodus file.  It'd definitely be worth a try, though.

It would be very nice if we can load the material directly from Abaqus
I'm working around this by:
-> map the properties values to element ID in .csv format
-> use PropertyReadFile to read it
-> then in my matprop.C file I use _read_prop_user_object->getData to map the properties into MOOSE matprop
Regards,
Traiwit

@dschwen @recuero who in the team uses Abaqus and has a workaround for this?
Or maybe should we add this feature now?

node.title: How to get the avarage value of variable at the quadrature points in an element?
node.bodyText:
I want to get the variable value on all Gaussian quadrature points (_q_point[_qp]) inside an element, and get the average value of them. Is there any way to distinguish the elements where different Gaussian integration points (_q_point[_qp]) are located? Or, is there any function to get the numbered values of all grid elements and iterate over all the numbers to retrieve the values on the Gaussian integration points (_q_point[_qp])?
In other words, how do I determine what cell number (_current_elem -> id()) corresponds to _qp when it is a definite number?

You cant match from _qp to the cell_id, _qp is the local index of the quadrature points when looping over elements.
The loops over all elements are built in ElementalUserObjects, and some GeneralUserObjects are doing this on their own.
Are you trying to project from a higher order variable to a CONST MONOMIAL that will be constant on each element?
If so, I d make a multiapp with a projection transfer then transfer that back to the main app
Thank you, Can Auxkernel do this projection?
the SelfAux is the closest to that but I dont think it will do the projection properly
check the code before you use it

Thank you. From high order to low order, I recently tried to implement it in the input file through auxiliary variables. I don't know if this is reasonable.
If I identify a cell, and I think I can do a small loop for all the Gauss points in the cell, is there any way to get an intermediate variable value on the Gauss points?

When I tried unstructured grids earlier, by outputting element numbers on the screen, I found that they were not sequential, or in order. Can I have all the element numbers(As far as I know, _current_elem->id() corresponds to the number of the previous cell, which is just a number)?

The _qp values from the current cell are all available in elemental loops
_current_elem is the id of the current cell.
You can loop over elements. Making a loop over the ids is not the way to go

Take a look at how we compute the element-averaged deformation gradient here: 
  
    
      moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/lagrangian/ComputeLagrangianStrainBase.C
    
    
        Lines 187 to 188
      in
      1cd91e6
    
  
  
    

        
          
           const auto F_avg = StabilizationUtils::elementAverage( 
        

        
          
               [this](unsigned int qp) { return _F_ust[qp]; }, _JxW, _coord); 
        
    
  


The utility that accepts a lambda or a functor in StabilizationUtils should be helpful.

As @hugary1995 shows, it is possible to do this within a Material.  For Kernels and other objects... I would recommend using the Auxiliary system.  An Auxkernel that just does return _coupled_value[_qp] that fills a CONSTANT MONOMIAL field will compute the element average of the coupled field.  You could then couple that into whatever you want.

node.title: RayTracing module: To trace the trajectory in a projectile motion
node.bodyText:
I want to trace the trajectory of a mass particle in a projectile motion using RayTracing module. First of all, is it possible?
If so, how should I proceed with it? Using Gravity kernel. So far from the examples, I could only find rays which are straight lines, is it possible to use RayTracingExodus to output non-linear trajectories?

Hello
It's possible, you can change the direction of each ray/particle at every time step.
It will still be linear on each time step.
Let me see if we can share an example with you
Guillaume
Thank you very much, an example would be very helpful and much appreciated.

Hii Guillaume,
Just a kind reminder for you to share an example to use ray tracing module to map the trajectory in a projectile motion.
Many thanks in advance.
--
Somnath

Hello
Sorry for the delay, took time to get approval and locate it
https://github.com/loganharbour/moose/tree/rt_mpm is an example of using the RT module to follow particles. Not everything is implemented yet. It seems only generation and contribution to some sort of mass matrix.
I think it s missing the part where the trajectory gets changed. However, having implemented this for monte carlo particle transport (using the RT module) I can help with that.
Guillaume
do you have access to that branch? If not we may ping Logan
@GiudGiud Many thanks for the example. Yes, I have access to this branch. I will try to implement my problem on this commit and will get back to you.

Hello @GiudGiud and @loganharbour, Thank you very much for the example of using ray tracing to follow the mass particles.
I ran the example and I have attached a screenshot of the result, where the bunch of mass particles move to their final location in 7 timesteps, but the ray tracing exodus could only produce the trace of the second last timestep. Also, the trace doesn't change with time.

Here I am attaching the lines I used for RayTracingExodus
[Outputs]
  exodus = true

  [rays]
    file_base = mpm_rays
    type = RayTracingExodus
    study = study
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]

In short, I have two questions and I would appreciate your help on these:

What could I do to get the transient trace of the rays?
If my mass particles move in a non-linear fashion, then the transient trace would also be non-linear, right?

Thank you very much for your help, it is highly appreciated, looking forward to your response.
--
Best Regards,
Somnath

The trace will be composed of segments. While the trace will not be linear, each segment, corresponding to a timestep, will be linear/straight


You can cache more ray tracing information by using these two booleans. I suspect the first one is all you need for this
These options need to be passed to the Ray tracing study, in the user objects


  # Needed to cache trace information for RayTracingMeshOutput
  # always_cache_traces = true
  # Needed to cache Ray data for RayTracingMeshOutput
  # data_on_cache_traces = true

Thank you for your prompt response, it is very good to know that a non-linear trace is possible. However I am still struggling to get more information stored in the RayTracingExodus. I am hereby attaching two blocks from the input file and they yielded the same result as in my previous comment.
[UserObjects]
  [study]
    type = MPMBoundingBoxRayStudy
    bbox_min = '0.05 0.8 0'
    bbox_max = '0.3 0.95 0'
    grid_intervals = '5 5'

    displacement = 'disp_x disp_y'
    mass = mass

    ray_kernel_coverage_check = false

    #To output rays
    always_cache_traces = true
    data_on_cache_traces = true

    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true

  [rays]
    file_base = mpm_rays
    type = RayTracingExodus
    study = study
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END FINAL'
  []
[]
do you mind attaching your output file? Maybe I ll understand the problem from there

Ofcourse, hereby I am attaching the exodus files and the input file as well.
mpm_test.zip
